title: Boston’s Vietnamese community celebrates Tết with culture and tradition
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Tết in Boston 2026 was held at the Menino Convention & Exhibition Center, attracting large crowds to celebrate Lunar New Year.
The festival featured traditional Vietnamese elements like calligraphy, Ao Dài dresses, and food, fostering cultural connection and immersion.
Organized by local Vietnamese associations, the event emphasized community gathering and cultural preservation across generations and ethnic backgrounds.

title: How a New Jersey runner is turning the 2026 Boston Marathon into a personal mission
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Kevin Brutus from Guttenberg, NJ is running the 2026 Boston Marathon in memory of his father.
Brutus joined Tedy's Team to raise awareness about heart disease and stroke impacting his family.
The race marks Brutus's 10th marathon, aiming to honor his father while supporting health research.

title: His future wife survived a medical emergency thanks to Boston MedFlight
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Sean Largay is running the 2026 Boston Marathon to fundraise for Boston MedFlight.
Maggie Bea, Largay's future wife, survived a medical emergency in 2024 with Boston MedFlight's assistance.
Boston MedFlight relies on donations to support their life-saving medical transport services.

title: He’s running the Boston Marathon to support young athletes
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: Ahmed Mansour, 45, from Houston, will run the 2026 Boston Marathon to support the Boston Athletic Academy.
Mansour aims to aid underprivileged youth by raising funds for mentorship, education, and athletics through his marathon efforts.
Completing the World Marathon Majors, Boston will be Mansour’s sixth race, with Sydney planned next for his 7-star goal.

title: American Eagle Outfitters to close Devens distribution facility, cutting 103 jobs
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: American Eagle Outfitters will close its Devens distribution facility, cutting 103 jobs starting April 12.
The facility at 64 Jackson Road was part of Quiet Logistics, acquired by American Eagle for $360 million in 2021.
The closure is part of a strategy to restructure logistics and focus on American Eagle's lifestyle brand portfolio.

title: Mass. lowers flags to half-staff in honor of fallen soldier Robert Arnold
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Massachusetts flags were lowered to half-staff to honor U.S. Army Staff Sgt. Robert R. Arnold from Roslindale.
Arnold, 27, served in both the U.S. Army and Marine Corps and graduated from Boston Latin School in 2016.
State Rep. Steve Xiarhos expressed condolences to Arnold's family, highlighting his dedication to service and sacrifice.

title: Healey, Ayotte spar over proposed ICE facility in N.H.
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Gov. Maura Healey and Gov. Kelly Ayotte are clashing over a proposed ICE detention facility in Merrimack, New Hampshire.
The proposed 324,000-square-foot facility would cost $158 million to retrofit, accommodating 400-600 beds and operational jobs.
Ayotte contested claims of prior knowledge of the ICE plans, demanding resignations and an investigation into communication failures.

title: Boy Scout rescued from Mount Washington after allergic reaction
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: A 15-year-old Boy Scout from Connecticut experienced a significant allergic reaction near the summit of Mount Washington.
The incident occurred Sunday afternoon, prompting a swift response from New Hampshire Fish and Game and local rescue teams.
Rescue crews transported the teen using a Snowcat to an ambulance, which took him to Androscoggin Valley Hospital.

title: New owner steps in at Grumpy’s
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Thomas Holmes, 28, buys Grumpy's in East Dennis, promising no changes to staff, menu, or operations.
Grumpy's sale attracted significant interest; property not included in sale, remains with previous owner Jim Manning.
Holmes aims to preserve Grumpy's as an iconic Cape Cod breakfast spot, maintaining its 30-year legacy without renovations.

title: Local obituary: John Rousanidis, Peabody 33-year-old and crewmember on Lily Jean
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: John Rousanidis, 33, of Peabody, died at sea on January 30, 2026, while working on a fishing vessel.
John had a strong connection with the sea, developed during his upbringing in Greece, and was known for his kindness.
A memorial service for John Rousanidis will be held at St. Vasilios Greek Orthodox Church in Peabody on February 20, 2026.
